metadata.case_name: Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. Loaned Employees v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay

facts.text: Appellants were originally in the service of the Scindia Steam Navigation Co. Ltd. (Scindias). Their services were transferred by way of loan to the Air Services of India Limited (ASI).
ASI was formed in 1937, purchased by the Scindias in 1943, and by 1946 was a full subsidiary of the Scindias.
From 1946 to about 1951, a large number of employees of the Scindias were transferred to the ASI for indefinite periods.
Scindias had a number of subsidiaries and it was usual to transfer employees to subsidiaries and take them back as necessary.

Loaned employees to ASI got the same scale of pay as Scindias employees, same terms and conditions of service including bonus, Scindias retained right to recall them, and they were entitled to go back to Scindias if desired.
Terms and conditions of loaned employees differed from those recruited directly by ASI.
In 1952, Government of India contemplated nationalisation of existing air lines effective June 1953.
Appellants addressed letter to Scindias on April 6, 1953, requesting to be taken back due to nationalisation.

Scindias replied on April 24, 1953, stating all ASI workers governed by cl. 20 of Air Corporations Bill, applies irrespective of recruitment source, option not to join under proviso treated as resignation, no retrenchment compensation, hoped no surplus staff.
Union replied on behalf of appellants on April 29, 1953, loaned staff should not be forced to Corporation, suggest direct recruits from subsidiaries go instead.
Suggestion taken up with Government but nothing came of it, as direct recruits did not want to return.

Scindias issued circular on May 6, 1953 to all ASI employees including loaned, reiterating cl.20, option under proviso treated as resignation with retirement benefits only, conditions same until altered.
Air Corporations Act, No. XXVII of 1953 passed on May 28, 1953.
Notice sent on June 17, 1953 to each employee to inform by July 10, 1953 if opting out under proviso to s.20(1), form to reach Chairman by registered post.
Appellants did not give notice as required by proviso to s.20(1).
Demand on June 8, 1953 on behalf of appellants for assurance to take back if retrenched by Corporation in 5 years.
Scindias replied July 3, 1953, could not agree to assurance.
Letter on July 8, 1953 on behalf of appellants rejecting May 6 circular.
Appellants did not exercise option under proviso by July 10, 1953.
August 1, 1953 notified as appointed day under s.16, ASI vested in Corporation, s.20(1) came into force.

Industrial Tribunal, Bombay award dated November 25, 1957 in Reference I.T. No. 24 of 1956 held appellants governed by s.20(1), became Corporation employees from Aug 1, 1953, no right to revert to Scindias, rejected claims.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellants (loaned employees) are governed by s.20(1) of the Air Corporations Act, 1953, despite being loaned from Scindias to ASI.
Whether the contract of service between appellants and Scindias was assignable and transferable by law.
Whether Scindias were bound to take back the appellants even if s.20(1) applies.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants not governed by s.20(1) as they were employees of Scindias, not ASI.
Contract of service between appellants and Scindias not assignable or transferable even by law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if s.20(1) applies, Scindias bound to take back appellants.

respondent_arguments.text: All persons working in ASI governed by cl.20/s.20(1) irrespective of recruitment source; option not to join treated as resignation.
Appellants informed of position on May 6, 1953, did not raise dispute immediately or exercise option by July 10, 1953; thus governed by s.20(1), became Corporation employees.
Could not agree to take back if retrenched by Corporation.

court_reasoning.text: S.20(1) ensures continuity of service for benefit of employees of existing air companies; no compulsion, proviso allows opt-out by notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object for benefit of employees; option to not join.

court_reasoning.text: Even if contract transfer argument correct, proviso allows free exit; distinguishes Nokes as statutory provision with option valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No compulsory transfer due to proviso.

court_reasoning.text: For s.20(1), check if employed by ASI prior to July 1, 1952 and still on appointed day; appellants were working for, paid by, controlled by ASI, thus employees despite special terms.
court_reasoning.key_observation: In law, employees of ASI subject to special terms.

court_reasoning.text: No right against Scindias after becoming Corporation employees by operation of law on Aug 1, 1953.

holdings.text: Appellants governed by s.20(1), became employees of Corporation from appointed day (Aug 1, 1953) as failed to opt out.
Contract of service transferable by statutory provision with opt-out; Nokes distinguished.
Scindias not bound to take back appellants post vesting.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Observation that personal service contract not transferable without consent, but statutory provision with opt-out valid.

statutes_cited.name: Air Corporations Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: S.20(1) transfers employees of existing air companies to Corporation with continuity unless opt-out; s.16 notifies appointed day.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Industrial Tribunal's award rejecting reference dismissed; appellants held to be employees of Corporation from August 1, 1953, with no rights to revert to Scindias or claim alternative benefits.

key_quotes.text: "every officer or other employee of an existing air company... employed by that company prior to the first day of July, 1952, and still in its employment immediately before the appointed day shall... become... an officer or other employee... of the Corporation"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Subject to these special terms, they would for all purposes be the employees of the ASI and thus would in law be in the employment of the ASI both on July 1, 1952 and on August 1, 1953."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines loaned employees as ASI employees for s.20(1).

key_quotes.text: "the provision of s. 20(1) read with the proviso is a perfectly reasonable provision and, as a matter of fact, in the interest of employees themselves."
key_quotes.speaker: court
